title: Avoid interrupting ZookeeperConsumerConnector.shutdown() #3346
body:
This is a less intrusive version of PR https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3351, fixing issue https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3346

The problem is that if the thread that executes `ZookeeperConsumerConnector.shutdown()` is interrupted, then the shutdown may fail to actually terminate the `ConsumerFetcherThread`s.

To avoid this, the following changes were made:
1. When cancelling the futures, set `mayInterruptIfRunning` to `false`
2. Make sure to always softly `shutdown()` the executor (instead of aggressively doing `shutdownNow()`).

Also, redundant checks like `!future.cancel() && !future.isDone()` were removed, since the javadoc of `cancel()` says that:

> `After this method returns, subsequent calls to {@link #isDone} will always return {@code true}`

(regardless of what `cancel` returns)

title: Documented the need for hadoop config after insert-segment-to-db
body:
Default file-system in 'core-site.xml' is required after running insert-segment-to-db when segments are stored in HDFS, since it saves all segment paths as relative URLs.

While running insert-segment-to-db, class io.druid.storage.hdfs.HdfsDataSegmentFinder changes the absolute path to relative.

While loading the segments using relative path, io.druid.storage.hdfs.HdfsDataSegmentPuller.getSegmentFiles calls path.getFileSystem(config), which (in absence of "fs.defaultFS" in Hadoop conf, in org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem) assumes it to be a file on local disc, even when type in segment metadata is set to hdfs.

title: Support finding segments in AWS S3.
body:
hello~

There is a tool called [`insert-segment-to-db`](http://druid.io/docs/latest/operations/insert-segment-to-db.html) which produces metadata from actual files(descriptor.json, index.zip) stored in various storages. It's cool to use when I migrate segments from one to another or when I totally lose metadata at all and recover it from the scratch.
However, I've found out that `insert-segment-to-db` does not support AWS S3 while I tried to regenerate metadata. That's why I made `S3DataSegmentFinder` to support finding segments in S3. There are some considerations I took as the below.
1. `S3DataSegmentPushConfig` is reused here as other classes in `druid-s3-extensions` in place of introducing another configuration object.
2. Since it is hard to write test codes to verify interations with S3, `MockStorageService` is introduced to mock `RestS3Service` up refering to `S3DataSegmentMoverTest`.

Thank you.

title: fix missing segments duplicate retried in RetryQueryRunner
body:
RetryQueryRunner will retry missing segments, but it always uses the origin missing segments among all retry attempts. 
This behaviors will cause incorrect query result because same segment is queried more than once.
It should use the latest missing segments for each retry attempt to avoid the duplication.

The log should look like this:

```
2016-08-26T05:08:03,834 INFO [main] io.druid.query.RetryQueryRunner - [2] missing segments found. Retry attempt [0]
2016-08-26T05:08:03,842 INFO [main] io.druid.query.RetryQueryRunner - [1] missing segments found. Retry attempt [1]
```

title: Support renaming of outputName for cached select and search query results
body:
As I know, Druid is designed able to use cached query result with different outputName.
For example,
query result cached with `DefaultDimentionSpec{dimension=a, outputName=out1}` is reused to respond to the query with `DefaultDimentionSpec{dimension=a, outputName=out2}` when the other part of query spec is identical. OutputName is renamed according to new DimensionSpec.

Currently, however, it does not work for select and search queries.
It returns previous outputName stored in cached result.

This patch enables renaming of outputName in cached result for select and search queries.

title: count/sum post aggregator from variance holder
body:
Variance holds count and sum (and nvariance). We can use of it.

This PR introduces `getInputTypeName()` in `AggregatorFactory` to acquire proper extractor for custom format. For example, basically variance can be calculated from serial numeric values from column. But in some case, we should accept pre-calculated variance something like `{"sum":x, "count":y, "nvar":z}` or `x:y:z`. This possibly can be done by using custom parser but it's redundant and not re-useable. If we can tip the type by specifying it in inputTypeName (`json-var` or 'num-var' for example), we can safely parse that to make variance holder in extractor.

title: fix cleanup of hadoop ingestion intermediate path
body:
currently, intermediate path is like...

```
/global-work-dir/dataSource/version/uuid
```

so when task runs, then "intermediate path" creation leads to creation of following 2 directories on hdfs (instead of just 1 directory) ...

```
/global-work-dir/dataSource/version
/global-work-dir/dataSource/version/uuid
```

and the cleanup would clean intermediate path and leaves following empty directory behind

```
/global-work-dir/dataSource/version
```

this patch changes the intermediate path to

```
/global-work-dir/dataSource/version_uuid
```

so that only 1 directory is created and then deleted appropriately which was also the behavior before https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2049

title: Add flag binaryAsString for parquet ingestion
body:
Hello,

This PR adds a flag "binaryAsString" to the "parquet" parser (extensions-contrib).

This is the equivalent of the Spark flag of the same name, used when you have a parquet generated by Impala. This flag tells the converter to interpret binary data as a string.

Without this patch, the strings are deserialized as an arrayish-string such as "[104, 101, 121, 32, 116..]" instead of the plain string.

title: Exhibitor Support
body:
This patch provides the integration of Druid & [Netflix Exhibitor](https://github.com/Netflix/exhibitor/wiki).

Exhibitor is a supervisor system for ZooKeeper. Exhibitor can dynamically scale-up/down the cluster of ZooKeeper servers. Druid currently use Apache Curator as ZooKeeper client. Curator can be integrated with Exhibitor to achieve a live/updating list of the ZooKeeper ensemble. For details, Please refer to [this link](http://curator.apache.org/exhibitor.html).

I want to use Exhibitor-supervised Zookeeper cluster for Druid. Please check this pull request.

Thanks.

title: [WIP, do not merge] Kafka lookups clobbering
body:
Fixing #3346 required introducing more strict state management. However, while I was there, I felt obliged to do some refactoring to increase maintainability.

I have reached a point where advancing further would be a bad idea before discussing it with original author(s) and other project collaborators. The main goals of this PR are:
- Untangle the lifecycle management and make it explicit
- Encapsulate the internal state of the class and stop directly mutating and checking it from within tests
- Split up large methods with loads of nested blocks into small manageable methods

More detailed comments on specific changes are made inline, see the diff.

Please bash this PR as hard as you can :) I must have violated quite some conventions.

**UPD: It might be much more convenient to view the changes as a split view instead of the unified diff.**

title: IncrementalIndex: Fix multi-value dimensions returned from iterators.
body:
They returned MapBasedRows with arrays as values, which its getDimension doesn't understand and therefore toStrings, leading to dimension values like "[Ljava.lang.Comparable;@67c277a0".

The only uses of these iterators in production code were in IndexGeneratorCombiner and in the v1 groupBy merging code. So useCombiner was likely broken for multi-value dims. groupBy shouldn't have been affected since it doesn't merge with multi-value dimensions.

title: Introduce standardized "Resource limit exceeded" error.
body:
Adds a "Resource limit exceeded" error code so callers can handle it differently from a generic server error.

Errors generated look like:

``` json
{
  "error": "Resource limit exceeded",
  "errorMessage": "Maximum number of rows [500000] reached",
  "errorClass": "io.druid.query.ResourceLimitExceededException",
  "host": "druid1.example.com:8083"
}
```

or:

``` json
{
  "error": "Resource limit exceeded",
  "errorMessage": "Grouping resources exhausted",
  "errorClass": "io.druid.query.ResourceLimitExceededException",
  "host": "druid1.example.com:8083"
}
```

Fixes #3336.

title: More useful query errors.
body:
Follow-up to #1773, which meant to add more useful query errors but
did not actually do so. Since that patch, any error other than
interrupt/cancel/timeout was reported as `{"error":"Unknown exception"}`.

With this patch, the error fields are:
- error, one of the specific strings "Query interrupted", "Query timeout",
  "Query cancelled", or "Unknown exception" (same behavior as before).
- errorMessage, the message of the topmost non-QueryInterruptedException
  in the causality chain.
- errorClass, the class of the topmost non-QueryInterruptedException
  in the causality chain.
- host, the host that generated the original exception.

title: Actually allow to create new kafka lookups
body:
The problem was that attempting to add a new Kafka-based lookup via API would return `202 ACCEPTED`, but the lookups would not actually appear in subsequent queries.

A quick investigation showed that all the other (`map` and `cachedNamespace`)  `LookupExtractorFactory.replaces()` implementations return `true` for `null`, but for Kafka it returns `false`.

With this change, adding a new lookup works fine.

title: optionally dump list of segment-ids used to process the query
body:
"/druid/v3" introduced in #3319 can handle larger context objects.

enabled by "dumpSegmentList" flag in the query context.

having the list of all segment-ids returned to user has 2 primary use-cases.
1. user can see exactly what timelines were found and not found, accordingly user can choose to use the result or error out or appropriately adjust the visualization.
2. some users have caches on top of druid that cache whole query results, they can use a hash of segments used in the cache key. users typically get the list of loaded segments from coordinator HTTP endpoints (or segment metadata query) and based on that they can check whether to use cached result or not.

i'm leaving this option undocumented intentionally for now as it should only be used with "/druid/v3" really.

title: Add time interval dim filter and retention analysis example
body:
This PR adds a new DimFilter that provides a convenient syntax for range filtering on long millisecond timestamp columns.

The new IntervalDimFilter accepts an array of ISO 8601 intervals, converts them into startMillis/endMillis ranges.

Its toFilter() method converts the IntervalDimFilter to an OR of BoundFilters from those millisecond ranges.

The PR also adds a test/docs demonstrating a basic retention analysis example, using the new time interval filter.

title: HLL: Avoid some allocations when possible.
body:
- HLLC.fold avoids duplicating the other buffer by saving and restoring its position.
- HLLC.makeCollector(buffer) no longer duplicates incoming BBs.
- Updated call sites where appropriate to duplicate BBs passed to HLLC.

Inspired by @navis's comment in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3111#issuecomment-236120591 (although I didn't go as far 😄 ).

Benchmarks, jdk1.8.0_60 (19–30% speedup depending on the test):

```
topN - master + sorting on hyperUniquesMet

Benchmark                                  (numSegments)  (rowsPerSegment)        (schemaAndQuery)  (threshold)  Mode  Cnt        Score       Error  Units
TopNBenchmark.queryMultiQueryableIndex                 1            750000                 basic.A           10  avgt   25   193478.532 ±  5680.045  us/op
TopNBenchmark.querySingleIncrementalIndex              1            750000                 basic.A           10  avgt   25  1571360.141 ± 37579.656  us/op
```

title: Fix FilteredAggregators at ingestion time and in groupBy v2 nested queries.
body:
The common theme between the two is they both create "fake" DimensionSelectors
that work on top of Rows. They both do it because there isn't really any
dictionary for the underlying Rows, they're just a stream of data. The fix for
both is to allow a DimensionSelector to tell callers that it has no dictionary
by returning CARDINALITY_UNKNOWN from getValueCardinality. The callers, in
turn, can avoid using it in ways that assume it has a dictionary.

Fixes #3311.

Also avoids setting the interrupted flag when InterruptedExceptions
happen, since this might interfere with resource closing, no other
query does it, and is probably pointless anyway since the thread
is likely to be a jetty thread that we don't actually want to set
an interrupt flag on.

Also fixes toString on OrderByColumnSpec.

title: streaming version of select query
body:
It is part of this discussion [https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/FK5D162ao74/13F3ixfJEQAJ](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/FK5D162ao74/13F3ixfJEQAJ)

This PR is a streaming version of select.
The query is similar to select query

``` json
{
    "queryType": "scan",
    "columns": [
        "q_sales","pv"
    ],
    "dataSource": "dws_tb_log_wl_100w_shard5",
    "limit": 10,
    "filter": {
        "dimension": "q_sales",
        "value": "55",
        "type": "selector"
    },
    "intervals": [
        "2015-01-01/2016-12-07"
    ]
}
```

The differences between select query and scan query, are
1. no pagingSpec, scan query reads events from the beginning to the end
2. select query returns 1 Object who contains a event list which is huge, like {[a,b,c,d,e,f,...]}, scan query returns list of small batch of events, like [ [a,b,c], [d,e,f], [...] ]
3. select query cost lots of memory because it has to buffer a huge list of events in memory, and flushes until the list is ready. scan query flushes when a small batch is ready, the client can get the batch while the server is preparing the next batch

It is tested by directly talking to historicals, and not fully tested from broker side.

title: Support Min/Max for Timestamp
body:
Related with #3298.
- Add an extension which provides two aggregator `timeMax` and `timeMin`.
- Internally, it stores timestamp value as Long so that we can have DateTime with group by query by finalizeComputing() but only get Long value with select query.
- To support parsing of string represented timestamp, TimestampSpec is slightly modified.
- Incremental index is also modified to accept many different type of timestamp at ingestion time.

title: Associate groupBy v2 resources with the Sequence lifecycle.
body:
This fixes a potential issue where groupBy resources could be allocated to
create a Sequence, but then the Sequence is never used, and thus the resources
are never freed.

I'm not sure if this would be an issue in production or not (it depends on whether
something doing merging would `run` a QueryRunner but then not use the Sequence).
It did cause issues in the unit tests though, and fixing it would be good in general, so
here is a patch.

Also simplifies how groupBy handles config overrides (this made the new
unit test easier to write).

title: Revert "Optionally intern ServerInventoryView inventory objects. (#3238)"
body:
This reverts commit a931debf790eaf4454ae13f35e11ba9d39765645.
Fixes #3283

The core issue here is that realtime nodes announce their size as 0, so a coordinator which interns the realtime version of the data segment will not be able to see the new sized announcement when handoff occurs.

This is caused by the `eauals` method on a `DataSegment` only evaluating the identifier. the `eauals` method _should_ be correct for object equivalence, and things which need to check equivalence of some sub-portion of the object should do so explicitly.

title: Do not consider full servers in CostBalancerStrategy
body:
Whenever a server is full or near full, the cost balancer will still keep picking that server to assign a segment to. When the server gets the load request, it will fail with a message similar to:

```
com.metamx.common.ISE: Segment[REDACTED:351,586,134] too large for storage[/redacted:18,952,315]
```

Which will show up as a bunch of `segment/assigned/count` in coordinator metrics. But the segment will not be loaded.

This changes behavior to simply skip considering servers which cannot hold a particular segment. If a suitable server is not found, it will show something like the following in the coordinator log:

```
2016-07-22T01:13:04,988 WARN [pool-8-thread-1] io.druid.server.coordinator.rules.LoadRule - Not enough [hot] servers or node capacity to assign segment[dataSource1_2010-01-01T00:00:00.000Z_2010-01-02T00:00:00.000Z_v1]! Expected Replicants[2]
2016-07-22T01:13:04,989 WARN [pool-8-thread-1] io.druid.server.coordinator.rules.LoadRule - Not enough [full] servers or node capacity to assign segment[dataSource1_2010-01-01T00:00:00.000Z_2010-01-02T00:00:00.000Z_v1]! Expected Replicants[1]
```

repo.name: druid

title: Add numeric StringComparator
body:
This PR adds a pure numeric StringComparator (supports decimals, negative numbers), used by the BoundFilter and GroupBy/TopN/Search queries.

The comparator will attempt to parse and compare Strings as BigDecimals.

Unparseable strings are treated as nulls, and nulls precede numbers. When comparing two strings that cannot be parsed as numbers, the comparator will order them lexicographically.

The BoundDimFilter interface has also been changed, deprecating "alphanumeric" in favor of an "ordering" String field.

The PR also unifies the existing lexicographic and alphanumeric TopNMetricSpecs (i.e., the ones that sort on dimension values) into a DimensionTopNMetricSpec, which can accept any of the 4 string comparators currently supported.

A similar unifying change is made for the SearchSortSpec (implemented in NewSearchSortSpec).

Fixes https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2989
# 

The following benchmarks show the performance difference between using this numeric comparator and the existing alphanumeric comparator on a long column (__time).

The `basic` data set spans an interval from (0,1000000) milliseconds.

`timeFilter` runs a timeseries query on the entire interval, using a filtered aggregator long sum with a BoundFilter for the __time interval (200000, 300000). The BoundFilter has an optimization that compares using long primitives if possible, when using the numeric comparator.

`timeFilterAlphanumeric` is the same as the previous query, but using the existing alphanumeric comparator instead.

`timeFilterByInterval` is a timeseries query on the interval (200000, 300000) with a long sum. This query is meant to provide a baseline comparison (interval based filtering vs. boundfilter on __time column). The interval based filtering is faster since the IncrementalIndex/QueryableIndex have optimizations that allow exclusion of rows using the interval (the boundfilter applied to the whole interval still has to read all of the rows)

```
TimeseriesBenchmark.queryMultiQueryableIndex                       1            750000              basic.timeFilter  avgt   50    19433.259 ±    66.505  us/op
TimeseriesBenchmark.queryMultiQueryableIndex                       1            750000  basic.timeFilterAlphanumeric  avgt   50   108962.170 ±  1877.408  us/op
TimeseriesBenchmark.queryMultiQueryableIndex                       1            750000    basic.timeFilterByInterval  avgt   50     7578.105 ±    20.135  us/op

TimeseriesBenchmark.querySingleIncrementalIndex                    1            750000              basic.timeFilter  avgt   50    69655.796 ±  2193.242  us/op
TimeseriesBenchmark.querySingleIncrementalIndex                    1            750000  basic.timeFilterAlphanumeric  avgt   50   144758.532 ±  3640.986  us/op
TimeseriesBenchmark.querySingleIncrementalIndex                    1            750000    basic.timeFilterByInterval  avgt   50    14898.808 ±   467.090  us/op

TimeseriesBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                      1            750000              basic.timeFilter  avgt   50    19668.441 ±    60.053  us/op
TimeseriesBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                      1            750000  basic.timeFilterAlphanumeric  avgt   50   101008.642 ±  1595.471  us/op
TimeseriesBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                      1            750000    basic.timeFilterByInterval  avgt   50     7490.932 ±    15.981  us/op
```

The following benchmark shows performance of the numeric comparator vs. alphanumeric in a TopN query:

```
Benchmark                                  (numSegments)  (rowsPerSegment)        (schemaAndQuery)  (threshold)  Mode  Cnt       Score       Error  Units
TopNBenchmark.queryMultiQueryableIndex                 1            750000       basic.numericSort           10  avgt   25  782488.365 ± 10153.742  us/op
TopNBenchmark.queryMultiQueryableIndex                 1            750000  basic.alphanumericSort           10  avgt   25  713468.221 ± 12023.384  us/op
TopNBenchmark.querySingleIncrementalIndex              1            750000       basic.numericSort           10  avgt   25  588548.252 ±  7134.410  us/op
TopNBenchmark.querySingleIncrementalIndex              1            750000  basic.alphanumericSort           10  avgt   25  534799.964 ±  7137.141  us/op
TopNBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                1            750000       basic.numericSort           10  avgt   25  391563.687 ±  6699.905  us/op
TopNBenchmark.querySingleQueryableIndex                1            750000  basic.alphanumericSort           10  avgt   25  351552.575 ±  7352.647  us/op
```

title: groupBy nested query using v2 strategy
body:
This PR changes the way v2 groupBy strategy process outer query using the result of inner query as datasource, addressing #3246. 

v1 groupBy strategy will use the same approach as before, by building an IncrementalIndex of inner query result, then use the query engine to process each interval on the built inner IncrementalIndex, and build an outer IncrementalIndex to merge the results.

v2 groupBy strategy will process the inner query results directly using a combined approach of process and merge with the v2 Grouper.

This change also fixes #3239 for v2 since AggregatorFactory.getRequiredColumn() is no longer used.

title: Reference counting, better error handling for resources in groupBy v2.
body:
Refcounting prevents releasing the merge buffer, or closing the concurrent
grouper, before the processing threads have all finished.

The better error handling prevents an avalanche of per-runner exceptions
when grouping resources are exhausted, by grouping those all up into a
single merged exception.

repo.name: druid
repo.description: Apache Druid: a high performance real-time analytics database.

title: Share query handling between Appenderator and RealtimePlumber.
body:
Makes changing the logic less error prone; otherwise there is a lot of similar but
slightly different code in the two files.

Also fixes inconsistent metric handling between the two implementations. Formerly,
RealtimePlumber only emitted query/segmentAndCache/time and query/wait, while
Appenderator only emitted query/partial/time and query/wait (all per sink).

Now they both do the same thing:
- query/segmentAndCache/time, query/segment/time are the time spent per sink.
- query/cpu/time is the CPU time spent per query. [new for both of them]
- query/wait/time is the executor waiting time per sink. [no change to either]

These generally match historical metrics, except segmentAndCache & segment
mean the same thing here, because one Sink may be partially cached and
partially uncached and we aren't splitting that out.

title: Better harmonized dimensions for query metrics.
body:
All query metrics now start with toolChest.makeMetricBuilder, and all of
_those_ now start with DruidMetrics.makePartialQueryTimeMetric. Also, "id"
moved to common code, since all query metrics added it anyway.

In particular this will add query-type specific dimensions like "threshold"
and "numDimensions" to servlet-originated metrics like query/time.
